title: Independent Work Cycle — Choosing Three Works
description: The child selects, completes, and returns three works from the shelf independently, demonstrating the full Montessori work cycle. This lesson marks the culmination of years of practical life development, showing the child's ability to self-direct their learning.
instructions:
1. Sit with the child near the work shelves.
2. 'Today you are going to choose THREE works from the shelf all by yourself. You will get each one, do the work, and put it back before choosing the next.'
3. Review the expectations: carry the tray carefully, work at a table or mat, complete the full cycle, return materials exactly as found.
4. Step back and observe. Do not intervene unless safety is a concern.
5. Note which works the child chooses, how long they concentrate, and how they handle transitions between works.
6. After all three works are complete, have a brief reflection: 'Tell me about the works you chose today.'
materials_needed: Prepared Montessori shelves with at least 8-10 available works

items: Prepared shelves with multiple work options
slides.setup_instructions: Ensure shelves are tidy and inviting with at least 8-10 works available. Include a mix of practical life, sensorial, and academic works.

slides.text: 'You have learned so many works this year! Today, YOU are the guide. Choose three works from the shelf, one at a time.'
'Remember the work cycle: choose your work, carry it carefully, do the work with focus, clean up, and return it to its place.'
'Take your time with each work. There is no rush. When you finish one, return it and then choose the next.'

slides.prompt: Choose and complete three works from the shelf independently. Take your time with each one and return it before starting the next.

slides.text: Reflect together: 'Which work was your favorite today? Was any work challenging? How did it feel to choose your own work?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently select, complete, and return three works without adult prompting or assistance?

parent_notes: This is a landmark lesson in Montessori education. The independent work cycle is the ultimate goal of the prepared environment — a child who can self-direct, concentrate, and complete meaningful work without adult intervention. Your role today is purely observational. Resist the urge to redirect, suggest, or correct. Note what the child gravitates toward — their choices reveal their developmental interests. If the child finishes quickly, they may be ready for longer work periods. If they struggle to choose, the shelves may need refreshing with new or more challenging works. Maria Montessori called this self-directed activity 'normalization' — the natural state of the child engaged in purposeful work.

title: Reading Comprehension — Written Responses
description: The child reads a short passage independently and answers comprehension questions in writing. This integrates reading fluency with written expression, moving the child toward the analytical reading skills needed for elementary.
instructions:
1. Present a short passage (4-6 sentences) at the child's reading level about an animal or nature topic.
2. 'Read this passage to yourself. Take your time and read it carefully.'
3. After reading, ask: 'What was this passage about? Tell me in your own words.'
4. Present three written questions: Who/What is it about? What happened? How did it end or what did you learn?
5. The child writes answers in complete sentences.
6. Review answers together, praising effort and content over spelling.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a 4-6 sentence passage about an interesting topic. Write 3 comprehension questions on a separate sheet.

slides.text: 'Today you are going to read a passage all by yourself, and then WRITE your answers to questions about it — just like a researcher!'
'First, read the passage silently. If you come to a tricky word, try to sound it out or look at the picture clues.'
'Now read these three questions. Write your answers in complete sentences — start with a capital letter and end with a period.'

slides.prompt: Read the passage carefully. Answer each question in a full sentence. Remember: capital letter, spaces between words, period at the end.

slides.text: Read your answers aloud. 'You wrote about what you read! That is what readers and writers do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a short passage independently and write at least 2 of 3 comprehension answers in recognizable sentences?

parent_notes: Written comprehension is a major milestone that bridges reading and writing. At this stage, prioritize content over perfect spelling — if the child communicates the correct answer, celebrate that. You can gently model correct spelling afterward: 'You wrote brd — that is so close! The word bird has an i in it: b-i-r-d.' Keep passages high-interest (animals, nature, adventures) and at a comfortable reading level. If the child struggles with writing, allow them to dictate one answer and write the other two. The goal is building confidence in expressing understanding through writing.

title: Subtraction Strip Board — Introduction
description: The child is introduced to the Montessori subtraction strip board, using the blue and red number strips to visualize taking away. This material makes subtraction concrete and prepares for memorization of subtraction facts.
instructions:
1. Present the subtraction strip board (numbered 1-18 across the top).
2. 'We have been adding. Now let's learn to SUBTRACT — to take away.'
3. Demonstrate: 7 - 3. Place the blue strip for 7. Then place the red strip for 3 starting from the 7 and counting back.
4. 'We started at 7, took away 3, and landed on 4. So 7 - 3 = 4!'
5. Practice together: 8 - 2, 9 - 5, 6 - 4.
6. Child works independently on 5-6 problems, recording answers on paper.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the strip board on a table. Organize blue strips on the left, red strips on the right. Have paper ready for recording.

slides.text: 'This is the subtraction strip board. We use it to figure out what happens when we TAKE AWAY. Subtraction means taking away.'
'Let's try 7 take away 3. First, place the blue 7 strip.' Place it starting from 1. 'The blue strip shows our starting number.'
'Now place the red 3 strip at the END of the blue strip, going backward. The red strip covers up what we take away.'
'Where does the blue strip peek out? At 4! So 7 take away 3 equals 4. Write it: 7 - 3 = 4.'

slides.prompt: Use the strip board to solve: 8 - 2, 9 - 5, 6 - 4, 10 - 3, 5 - 1, 9 - 7. Write each equation and answer.

slides.text: 'The strip board shows us exactly what subtraction looks like — taking away part of a number to see what is left!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly set up and solve at least 4 of 6 subtraction problems using the strip board?

parent_notes: The subtraction strip board is the counterpart to the addition strip board your child has already mastered. It makes subtraction visual and tactile — the child literally sees the number getting smaller as the red strip covers part of the blue strip. This is far more meaningful than memorizing facts in isolation. Let the child work slowly and check their own answers by counting. Some children find it helpful to think of subtraction as 'what is left' rather than 'take away.' Both framings are valid. If your child already knows some subtraction facts from daily life, celebrate that and let the board confirm what they know.

title: Continents Review — Animals of Each Continent
description: The child reviews all seven continents and identifies characteristic animals found on each one. This integrates geography knowledge with zoology, deepening the child's understanding of how living things are connected to their environments.
instructions:
1. Lay out the world puzzle map or a large world map.
2. Review each continent name using a three-period review.
3. Present animal figurines or picture cards sorted by continent.
4. 'Every continent has special animals that live there. Let's discover which animals belong where!'
5. Place animals on their continents together: kangaroo-Australia, elephant-Africa, panda-Asia, etc.
6. Child matches remaining animals independently.
7. Discuss why certain animals live only in certain places (climate, habitat).
materials_needed: World puzzle map or large world map
Animal figurines or picture cards (at least 2-3 per continent)

slides.heading: Animals of the Continents
slides.subheading: Where in the World Do They Live?

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the world map. Sort animal figures or cards into a basket. Have continent name labels ready.

slides.text: 'Let's review our continents! Can you name all seven?' Touch each one on the map as the child names them.
'Every continent has special animals. A kangaroo lives in Australia — place it there! An elephant lives in Africa.' Model placing animals.
'Why do you think polar bears live in the Arctic near North America and not in Africa? Think about what they need to survive.'

slides.prompt: Match each animal to its continent on the map. Can you name at least two animals for each continent?

slides.text: 'Animals live where they can find the food, weather, and habitat they need. You know animals from all around the world!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all 7 continents and correctly place at least 10 animals on the appropriate continents?

parent_notes: This lesson synthesizes two years of geography and zoology work. By now your child should know the continent names confidently. Adding the animal layer creates a richer mental map of the world. Use this as a springboard for further research: 'Would you like to learn more about animals in South America?' The Montessori approach to geography always connects the physical world to the living world — continents are not just shapes on a map but real places where real creatures live. If you have animal figurines (Safari Ltd Toob sets are excellent), they make this lesson especially engaging.

title: Read-Aloud: The Five Senses by Aliki
description: Reading about the five senses introduces the week's science theme. The child listens, discusses, and connects the book content to their own sensory experiences, building vocabulary and comprehension skills.
instructions:
1. Show the cover: 'This book is about something very special — our five senses! Do you know what they are?'
2. Let the child name as many senses as they can.
3. Read aloud, pausing to engage each sense: 'What do you see right now? What do you hear?'
4. After reading, create a five senses chart together: list one example for each sense.
5. 'This week in science, we will explore each sense in detail!'
materials_needed: The Five Senses by Aliki (or similar five senses book)

items: The Five Senses by Aliki or similar book
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a cozy reading area. Have chart paper ready for the five senses chart after reading.

slides.text: 'Our bodies have five amazing ways to experience the world — our five senses! Let's read and find out about each one.'
Read the book aloud. Pause at each sense: 'Close your eyes — what do you HEAR right now? That is your sense of hearing!'
After reading: 'Let's make a chart! Five columns — one for each sense. Can you think of one thing for each?'

slides.prompt: Help fill in the five senses chart with examples from your life. Sight: sunset. Hearing: bird songs. Touch: soft blanket. Taste: apple. Smell: flowers.

slides.text: 'Your senses help you learn about everything around you! This week we will become sense scientists.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all five senses and give at least one example for each?

parent_notes: This read-aloud sets the stage for a week of five senses exploration in science. The book by Aliki is a classic, but any age-appropriate five senses book works well. The key is making the content experiential — pause during reading to actually use each sense. The chart activity bridges listening comprehension to written recording. If your child is an eager writer, let them write the chart entries themselves. This is a beautiful example of how Montessori integrates subjects: a read-aloud introduces a science theme while practicing language skills.

title: Mystery Bag — Identifying Objects by Touch Alone
description: The child reaches into a cloth bag to identify objects using only their sense of touch (stereognostic sense). This advanced sensorial work sharpens tactile discrimination and builds the mental imagery skills needed for abstract thinking.
instructions:
1. Present the mystery bag with 8-10 small objects inside (key, button, shell, coin, marble, small animal figurine, pencil, eraser, paperclip, wooden block).
2. 'Today we will use ONLY our sense of touch. No peeking!'
3. Demonstrate: reach in, feel one object without looking, describe its properties (smooth, rough, round, flat, pointed), then name it before pulling it out.
4. The child takes turns feeling, describing, and identifying each object.
5. Increase difficulty: add similar objects (two different coins, two different buttons).
6. Child can sort identified objects by property (smooth vs. rough, round vs. flat).

slides.setup_instructions: Place objects in the bag without the child seeing. Include a variety of textures, shapes, and sizes.

slides.text: 'Your hands can tell you so much without your eyes! Today we use only our sense of TOUCH to identify objects in the mystery bag.'
Demonstrate: reach in, feel slowly. 'I feel something smooth and round and flat... it is a coin!' Pull it out to verify.
'Your turn! Reach in, feel carefully, and DESCRIBE what you feel before you name it. Smooth or rough? Big or small? Round or flat?'

slides.prompt: Identify all objects in the mystery bag using only your sense of touch. Describe each one before naming it. Then sort them: smooth things and rough things.

slides.text: 'Your fingers are amazing sensors! You identified objects without even seeing them. That is your stereognostic sense.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify at least 6 of 8 objects by touch alone and describe at least 2 properties of each?

parent_notes: The mystery bag (stereognostic bag) is one of Montessori's most elegant exercises. It develops the stereognostic sense — the ability to perceive and recognize the form of objects through touch. This skill is directly related to mathematical understanding (mental geometry) and reading (forming mental images from text). Encourage the child to use precise vocabulary: 'It has edges,' 'It is cylindrical,' 'It tapers to a point.' As the child masters familiar objects, increase difficulty by adding unfamiliar items or objects that are very similar in shape but different in texture.

title: Introduction to Research — Choosing a Topic
description: The child selects a topic of personal interest and begins learning how to research by gathering facts from books and simple reference materials. This lesson introduces the research process that will be central to elementary education.
instructions:
1. 'In school, when you want to learn about something, you do RESEARCH. That means finding facts and information about a topic.'
2. Present 4-5 topic options (animals, planets, weather, plants, ocean) with related books available.
3. The child chooses one topic.
4. 'Let's find THREE FACTS about your topic.' Open a reference book together.
5. Read a short section. 'What is one fact you learned?' Write it on a fact card.
6. Continue until the child has 3 fact cards.
7. 'You just did research! Researchers find facts and write them down.'
materials_needed: 4-5 age-appropriate reference books on different topics

slides.heading: Becoming a Researcher
slides.subheading: Choosing a Topic and Finding Facts

slides.setup_instructions: Display 4-5 topic cards with a related book for each. Prepare blank index cards for recording facts.

slides.text: 'Scientists and researchers learn about things by reading, observing, and writing down what they discover. Today, YOU are a researcher!'
'First, choose a topic that interests you.' Present the options. 'Which one would you like to learn more about?'
'Now let's open this book and find FACTS — true information. Listen carefully as I read this part.' Read a short passage.
'What did you learn? Tell me one fact.' Write the child's words on a fact card. 'That is your first research fact!'

slides.prompt: Find three facts about your chosen topic. Listen as the book is read, then tell your fact in your own words. Write or dictate each fact on an index card.

slides.text: 'You have three facts about your topic! Next time, we will find more facts and start writing a mini-report.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child choose a topic, listen to reference material, and identify at least 3 distinct facts?

parent_notes: Research skills are the bridge between primary and elementary Montessori. In elementary, children conduct extensive research projects called 'going out' — investigating topics deeply and presenting their findings. This lesson plants that seed. Let the child choose freely; their intrinsic interest will fuel the work. If they choose dinosaurs for the tenth time, that is perfect — deep interest leads to deep learning. The fact cards will be used in upcoming lessons to write a mini-report. Keep the process joyful and low-pressure. The child is learning HOW to learn, which is the most important skill of all.

title: Subtraction Strip Board — Subtracting from 10
description: The child uses the subtraction strip board to systematically work through all subtraction combinations that start with 10. This builds toward memorization of subtraction facts and deepens understanding of number relationships.
instructions:
1. Review the strip board setup from yesterday.
2. 'Today we will find ALL the ways to subtract from 10!'
3. Start with 10 - 1: place the blue 10 strip, then the red 1 strip. 'What is left? 9!'
4. Record: 10 - 1 = 9.
5. Continue systematically: 10 - 2 = 8, 10 - 3 = 7... through 10 - 9 = 1.
6. 'Do you see a pattern?' Guide the child to notice the answers count down.
7. The child reads the complete list of facts aloud.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the strip board. Prepare a recording sheet with equations: 10 - 1 = ___, 10 - 2 = ___, etc.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned how the strip board works. Today we will find EVERY subtraction fact for 10!'
'Start with the blue 10 strip. Now place the red 1. What number can you see? 9! So 10 - 1 = 9. Write it down.'
'Keep the blue 10. Now change to the red 2 strip. What is left? 8! 10 - 2 = 8.'
Continue through all combinations. 'Do you notice a pattern? As the red strip gets bigger, the answer gets...' (smaller!)

slides.prompt: Complete all subtraction facts from 10: 10 - 1 through 10 - 9. Record each answer. Read all nine facts aloud when done.

slides.text: 'You found all the subtraction facts for 10! The answers count backward: 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1. Subtraction is the reverse of addition!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete all subtraction-from-10 facts using the strip board and identify the descending pattern in the answers?

parent_notes: Working systematically through all subtraction facts for a single number is a Montessori approach to building number sense. The child discovers patterns rather than memorizing isolated facts. The key insight — that as the subtrahend increases, the difference decreases — is foundational for algebraic thinking later. Making 10 is especially important because it is the basis for mental math strategies. If your child notices that 10 - 3 = 7 and 10 - 7 = 3, celebrate that discovery! They are seeing the inverse relationship, which is a sophisticated mathematical understanding.

title: The Five Senses — Sense of Sight
description: An in-depth exploration of the sense of sight. The child learns about how eyes work, conducts observation experiments, and discovers how sight helps us learn about the world around us.
instructions:
1. 'Which sense do you think you use the most? Many people say SIGHT — our eyes!'
2. Look at a simple diagram of the eye. Name the parts: pupil, iris, eyelid, eyelash.
3. Experiment 1: Look in a mirror — observe the pupil in bright light versus dim light. 'Your pupil gets bigger in the dark to let in more light!'
4. Experiment 2: Color mixing — use colored cellophane to see how colors change when layered.
5. Experiment 3: 'I Spy' with increasingly specific descriptions.
6. Record observations in the science journal.

slides.heading: The Five Senses
slides.subheading: Our Amazing Eyes — Sense of Sight

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a well-lit workspace. Have the mirror, cellophane, and flashlight ready. Print or draw a simple eye diagram.

slides.text: 'Your eyes are incredible! They take in light and send messages to your brain about shapes, colors, and movement. Let's explore!'
'Look at this eye diagram. The colored part is the IRIS. The black circle is the PUPIL — it is a tiny hole that lets light in!'
'Look in the mirror. See your pupil? Now cover your eyes for 10 seconds, then look again. Did your pupil change?' (It gets bigger in dark, smaller in light.)
'Now let's see how our eyes see COLOR.' Look through red cellophane, then blue. 'What happens when you layer red and blue together?'

slides.prompt: Draw your own eye in your science journal. Label the iris and pupil. Write or draw one thing you discovered about sight today.

slides.text: 'Your eyes adjust to light, see millions of colors, and help you read, explore, and stay safe. What an amazing sense!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the pupil and iris, explain that the pupil changes size with light, and describe how colored cellophane changes what we see?

parent_notes: This begins a week-long deep dive into the five senses, connecting to the Montessori emphasis on sensorial education. Maria Montessori believed that all learning enters through the senses, which is why sensorial materials are so central to her method. The pupil experiment is genuinely fascinating for children and teaches real science. If your child wears glasses, this is a wonderful time to discuss how lenses help eyes focus. The color-mixing with cellophane is a precursor to understanding light and color science. Encourage your child to notice how they use sight throughout the day — 'I am using my sense of sight to read this book!'

title: Observational Drawing — Drawing What You See
description: The child practices observational drawing by carefully studying a natural object and drawing it from life. This integrates the day's sight exploration with artistic expression and fine motor development.
instructions:
1. 'Artists look very carefully before they draw. Today we are going to draw EXACTLY what we see — not from imagination, but from observation.'
2. Place a natural object (flower, shell, leaf, pinecone) in front of the child.
3. 'Before you draw, LOOK. What shapes do you see? What colors? Are there patterns?'
4. Spend 2 full minutes just looking and describing.
5. The child draws the object using pencil first for outline, then colored pencils for detail.
6. 'Compare your drawing to the real object. What did you capture well?'
materials_needed: Natural object (flower, shell, leaf, or pinecone)

slides.setup_instructions: Place the natural object at eye level on a plain background. Provide good lighting. Set out drawing materials.

slides.text: 'Today we are OBSERVATION artists. That means we draw exactly what our eyes see — every detail, every color, every line.'
'First, just LOOK. Do not draw yet. What shapes do you notice? Circles? Lines? Curves? What colors do you see?'
'Now start with light pencil lines for the big shapes. Then add smaller details. Take your time — there is no rush.'

slides.prompt: Draw the natural object as carefully as you can. Look, then draw. Look again. Add color when the outline is done. Try to include at least 3 details you noticed.

slides.text: 'Hold your drawing next to the real object. You captured it with your own hands! Observational drawing trains our eyes AND our hands.'
slides.mastery_check: Does the child's drawing show evidence of careful observation — recognizable shape, at least 3 accurate details, and appropriate colors?

parent_notes: Observational drawing is a cornerstone of Montessori art education and connects beautifully to today's sight exploration. The key is the looking phase — rushing to draw without careful observation produces generic images. Montessori observed that children who spend time really seeing an object produce remarkably detailed drawings. Do not correct the child's drawing or show them 'how' to draw the object. Their interpretation is valid. Instead, ask guiding questions: 'I see you drew the petals — did you notice how they overlap?' A magnifying glass can reveal details that excite and inspire the child to include more in their drawing.

title: Independent Work Cycle — Self-Assessment
description: The child completes another independent work cycle of three works, but this time adds self-assessment by rating their own concentration and effort. This builds metacognition — thinking about their own thinking and learning.
instructions:
1. Review the work cycle expectations.
2. Introduce the self-assessment: 'After each work, you will give yourself a rating. Were you focused? Did you do your best?'
3. Show the simple rating system: star (excellent focus), check (good focus), circle (needs more practice).
4. The child selects and completes three works independently.
5. After each work, the child marks their self-assessment on a simple chart.
6. Discuss the ratings together: 'Why did you give yourself a star for that work? What made it easy to focus?'
materials_needed: Self-assessment chart (3 rows, columns for work name and rating)

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simple chart with spaces for 3 works. Include columns for: Work Name, How I Focused (star/check/circle).

slides.text: 'Today you will choose three works again, AND you will be your own teacher! After each work, you rate how well you focused.'
'Star means: I concentrated the whole time and did my best. Check means: I focused pretty well. Circle means: I found it hard to focus today.'
'Remember, there is no wrong answer. Being honest about your own work is what great learners do.'

slides.prompt: Choose and complete three works. After each one, write the work name on your chart and give yourself an honest rating.

slides.text: 'Let's look at your chart together. Tell me about each work and why you rated yourself that way. What helped you focus?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete three works independently AND meaningfully self-assess their concentration and effort?

parent_notes: Self-assessment is a critical skill that Montessori education develops naturally. When children evaluate their own work, they develop internal motivation rather than dependence on external praise. The rating system should be non-judgmental — a 'circle' is not bad, it is honest reflection. Ask open-ended questions: 'What was different about the work where you gave yourself a star?' Children often identify environmental factors (noise, hunger, interest level) that affect concentration. This metacognitive awareness is remarkably sophisticated for this age and serves them well throughout their education.

title: Reading Comprehension — Making Predictions
description: The child reads a passage, makes predictions about what will happen next, and then reads on to check their predictions. This active reading strategy develops higher-order thinking and engagement with text.
instructions:
1. Present a short story in two parts (stop point in the middle).
2. 'Read the first part carefully. Then STOP — do not peek at the rest!'
3. After reading Part 1: 'What do you think will happen next? Why do you think that?'
4. The child writes their prediction.
5. 'Now read Part 2 and find out!'
6. After reading: 'Was your prediction correct? Were you close? It is okay if it was different — good readers make predictions even when they are not exactly right.'
materials_needed: Two-part story printed on separate pages
Prediction worksheet (What I think will happen / What actually happened)

slides.setup_instructions: Print the story on two separate pages so Part 2 is hidden. Prepare a simple prediction worksheet.

slides.text: 'Good readers do not just read words — they THINK while they read. One way to think is to predict: guess what will happen next!'
'Read Part 1 of this story. When you get to the STOP sign, put the paper down.'
'Now — what do you THINK will happen next? Use clues from the story. Write your prediction on this sheet.'
'Now read Part 2. Did what you predicted actually happen? Write what REALLY happened next to your prediction.'

slides.prompt: Read Part 1, write your prediction, then read Part 2 and compare. Draw a picture of the ending.

slides.text: 'Predicting makes reading exciting — it is like being a detective! Every time you read, try to guess what will happen next.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child make a logical prediction based on story clues and compare their prediction to the actual outcome?

parent_notes: Prediction is one of the most powerful reading comprehension strategies. It transforms passive reading into active engagement. The child is using context clues, character knowledge, and story structure to make educated guesses — all higher-order thinking skills. The key is validating ALL predictions, not just correct ones. A 'wrong' prediction still shows thinking: 'Your prediction was different from the story, but it made sense based on what you knew! That is excellent thinking.' This strategy naturally transfers to independent reading — children who predict while reading comprehend more deeply.

title: Subtraction Facts — Memorization with Finger Charts
description: The child begins memorizing basic subtraction facts using Montessori finger charts and repetition. Building fluency with subtraction facts prepares the child for more complex mathematical operations.
instructions:
1. Present the Subtraction Finger Chart (or a simplified version showing facts to 10).
2. 'You have been discovering subtraction facts on the strip board. Now let's start remembering them!'
3. Start with the easiest facts: subtracting 1. '5 - 1 = ? Can you answer without the strip board?'
4. Work through subtracting 1 from each number 2-10.
5. Then subtracting 2: '6 - 2 = ?, 7 - 2 = ?'
6. Use flash cards for review. The child sorts cards into 'I know it' and 'I need practice.'
7. Celebrate the 'I know it' pile!
materials_needed: Subtraction finger chart (or printed subtraction chart)
Two baskets (I know it / I need practice)

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare flash cards for subtracting 1 and 2 from numbers 2-10. Label baskets 'I Know It' and 'Still Learning.'

slides.text: 'You have used the strip board to find subtraction answers. Now let's see how many you can remember WITHOUT the board!'
'Let's start easy: subtracting 1. If you have 5 and take away 1... the answer is the number right before 5!'
Show flash cards one at a time. 'Say the answer as fast as you can. If you know it quickly, it goes in the I Know It basket!'
'If you need to think longer, that is perfectly fine — it goes in the Still Learning basket. We will practice those more.'

slides.prompt: Sort all the flash cards. Try to answer each one from memory. Use the strip board to check any you are unsure about. How many are in your I Know It basket?

slides.text: 'Look at how many facts you already know! We will keep practicing the Still Learning pile until they all move over.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recall at least 10 subtraction facts (subtracting 1 and 2) from memory within 3 seconds each?

parent_notes: Montessori approaches fact memorization after extensive concrete experience — your child has spent weeks with the strip board discovering these facts. Now the transition to memorization is natural, not rote. The two-basket sorting method gives the child ownership over their learning and removes shame from not knowing. Never rush this process. Some children memorize quickly; others need more concrete work first. If the 'Still Learning' basket is large, return to the strip board for those facts. The Montessori finger charts are a bridge between concrete materials and abstract recall — the child can reference them independently.

title: Poetry Study — Writing an Original Poem
description: The child writes an original poem about one of their five senses, using descriptive language and simple poetic structures. This integrates language arts with the week's science theme and celebrates creative expression.
instructions:
1. Read 2-3 short poems about the senses (e.g., 'I see...', 'I hear...' format).
2. 'Poets write about what they notice. What sense would you like to write about?'
3. Brainstorm together: list 5-6 sensory words for the chosen sense.
4. Model writing a simple poem: 'I hear the rain / tapping on the window / like tiny fingers drumming.'
5. The child writes their own poem (3-5 lines). Accept invented spelling.
6. The child reads their poem aloud.
7. Illustrate the poem.
materials_needed: Special poetry paper (lined with illustration space)

slides.setup_instructions: Print or write 2-3 simple sense poems. Prepare poetry paper with lines at the bottom and space for illustration at the top.

slides.text: 'Poets notice the world with their senses and turn what they notice into beautiful words. Listen to this poem...' Read examples.
'Which sense would YOU like to write about? What do you love to see, hear, touch, taste, or smell?'
'Let's think of words first.' Create a word bank together: soft, bright, sweet, loud, crunchy, warm, sparkly...

slides.prompt: Write your own poem about one of the five senses. Use at least 3 sensory words. Your poem should be 3-5 lines. Then draw a picture to go with it.

slides.text: 'Read your poem to me! You are a poet. Your words paint a picture in my mind.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a 3-5 line poem using descriptive sensory language and read it aloud?

parent_notes: Poetry is a natural fit for Montessori's emphasis on precise language and sensory awareness. Young children are natural poets — they notice details adults overlook and describe things in fresh, vivid ways. The key to this lesson is the brainstorming phase. Building a word bank removes the blank-page anxiety and gives the child material to work with. Accept all spelling attempts joyfully — this is creative expression, not a spelling test. If the child dictates while you write, that is fine too. Read the poem aloud with expression to show the child that their words are powerful and worth celebrating.

title: Read-Aloud: My Five Senses by Margaret Miller
description: A photograph-rich book that explores how children use their five senses in everyday life. The read-aloud reinforces the science theme and gives the child language for describing sensory experiences.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'We have been learning about senses all week! This book shows real children using their senses.'
2. Read aloud. At each sense, pause and connect to the child's experience: 'When do YOU use your sense of hearing?'
3. After reading, play a quick game: name an activity and the child identifies which senses are used.
4. 'Eating ice cream — which senses?' (Taste, touch, sight, smell!)
5. 'Playing in the rain?' (Touch, sight, hearing, smell!)
6. Record favorite examples in the science journal.
materials_needed: My Five Senses by Margaret Miller (or similar)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: My Five Senses by Margaret Miller

items: My Five Senses or similar book
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the reading area. Have the science journal ready for after-reading activity.

slides.text: 'This book has photographs of real children using their five senses. Let's see if we use our senses the same way!'
Read each page. Pause: 'The girl is smelling flowers. When do you use your sense of smell?'
After reading, play the Senses Game: 'I will name something, you tell me which senses you use!'

slides.prompt: Play the Senses Game: eating pizza (taste, smell, sight, touch), swimming (touch, sight, hearing), listening to music (hearing). Write 3 favorites in your journal.

slides.text: 'Most activities use MORE than one sense at a time! Our senses work together to help us experience the world.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify multiple senses used in a single activity and articulate which sense is dominant?

parent_notes: This read-aloud deepens the five senses theme by showing the child that most real-world experiences are multi-sensory. The photograph format is especially powerful for young children because it shows real, relatable situations. The game after reading is excellent for developing analytical thinking — the child must break down a complex experience into its sensory components. You can continue this game throughout the day: at meals, during outdoor time, or before bed. It builds awareness and vocabulary simultaneously.

title: Sound Cylinders — Matching and Grading
description: The child works with Montessori sound cylinders (or homemade equivalents) to match pairs of cylinders by sound and grade them from softest to loudest. This refines auditory discrimination and connects to the five senses theme.
instructions:
1. Present two sets of sound cylinders (6 pairs with different fill materials).
2. 'Today we are using our sense of HEARING very carefully. These cylinders each make a different sound.'
3. Shake one cylinder from Set A. 'Listen carefully. Now find its match in Set B.' Shake Set B cylinders one at a time.
4. When a match is found, place them together.
5. Continue until all 6 pairs are matched.
6. Extension: grade one set from softest to loudest.
7. Verify by shaking each in order.
materials_needed: Sound cylinders (2 sets of 6) or homemade equivalent (small containers with rice, beans, sand, beads, salt, pebbles)

items: Two sets of sound cylinders (6 pairs)
slides.setup_instructions: Place Set A on the left and Set B on the right. If making your own, fill pairs of containers with identical amounts of: rice, beans, sand, small beads, salt, pebbles.

slides.text: 'We explored sight and touch this week. Today we focus on HEARING. These cylinders each make a different sound. Listen!'
Shake one from Set A. 'Now shake each one from Set B until you find the one that sounds the SAME.' Demonstrate careful listening.
'When you find a match, place them together. Keep going until all pairs are matched.'
'Now let's GRADE them! Can you put one set in order from the softest sound to the loudest sound?'

slides.prompt: Match all 6 pairs by sound. Then grade one set from softest to loudest. Try doing it with your eyes closed for a challenge!

slides.text: 'Your ears can tell the difference between very similar sounds! That is your auditory sense — and you just proved how sharp it is.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 5 of 6 sound pairs and grade them in approximate order from soft to loud?

parent_notes: Sound cylinders are a classic Montessori sensorial material that isolate the sense of hearing. If you do not own the official cylinders, they are easy to make: use identical small containers (film canisters, spice jars, or plastic eggs) and fill pairs with identical materials. The matching activity requires careful listening and comparison — children must hold the sound in memory while comparing to another cylinder. The grading activity (soft to loud) is more challenging because it requires ordering along a continuum. This work directly develops the auditory discrimination needed for phonics and music.

title: Research Skills — Finding More Facts
description: The child continues their research project by finding additional facts from a second source. They learn that researchers use multiple sources to verify and expand their knowledge.
instructions:
1. Review the 3 fact cards from Day 2.
2. 'Researchers do not stop at one book! Let's find MORE facts from a different source.'
3. Present a second book or printed article about the child's chosen topic.
4. Read together and find 3 new facts that are DIFFERENT from the first 3.
5. Write each new fact on a card.
6. 'Now you have 6 facts! Let's organize them — which facts go together?'
7. Help the child sort fact cards into 2-3 groups.
materials_needed: Second reference source on the same topic

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the 3 fact cards from the previous session. Have the second source ready.

slides.text: 'Let's look at your fact cards from last time.' Read them aloud. 'Great facts! Now let's find even MORE from a different book.'
'Real researchers use more than one source. That way they learn more and can check that their facts are correct.'
Read from the second source together. 'What new fact did you learn? Is it different from your other cards? Write it down!'
'Now let's organize! Spread out all 6 cards. Which facts are about the same thing? Group them together.'

slides.prompt: Find 3 new facts from the second source. Write each on a card. Then sort all 6 cards into groups of related facts.

slides.text: 'You have 6 organized facts! Next time, we will use these to write a mini-report. You are becoming a real researcher!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify new facts from a second source and sort all facts into logical categories?

parent_notes: Using multiple sources is a fundamental research skill that your child will use throughout their education. At this age, the 'sources' can be simple — two different books about dolphins, or a book and a printed article. The organizing step is especially important because it teaches the child to categorize information, which is the basis of outlining and structured writing. If the child finds a fact that contradicts or adds to an earlier fact, celebrate that: 'Interesting! This book says something a little different. That means we might need to investigate more!' This mirrors real scholarly inquiry.

title: Word Problems — Introduction with Subtraction
description: The child is introduced to word problems using concrete objects and familiar scenarios. This bridges the gap between manipulative-based math and real-world problem solving.
instructions:
1. 'Math is not just numbers on paper — math is everywhere! Let's solve some real-life math stories.'
2. Tell a simple story: 'You had 8 apples. You gave 3 to your friend. How many do you have left?'
3. Act it out with real objects (8 counters, remove 3).
4. 'What math did we just do? 8 - 3 = 5! That is a word problem.'
5. Tell 3-4 more stories, each time having the child identify the operation and solve with objects.
6. The child writes the equation for each story.
7. Bonus: the child creates their own word problem for the parent to solve.
materials_needed: Counting objects (buttons, beads, or small toys)
Paper and pencil for recording equations

slides.setup_instructions: Gather 20 counting objects. Prepare 4-5 simple word problems using scenarios familiar to the child.

slides.text: 'Math happens in real life every day! When you share cookies or count how many are left, that is math. Let's practice with math stories.'
'Listen to this story: You had 8 apples. You gave 3 to your friend. How many apples do you have now?' Use objects to act it out.
'You started with 8, took away 3, and have 5 left. The equation is 8 - 3 = 5. You just solved a word problem!'
'Here is another: There were 10 birds on a fence. 4 flew away. How many are still on the fence?' Solve with objects, write the equation.

slides.prompt: Solve 3 more word problems using objects and write the equations. Then make up YOUR own word problem for someone else to solve!

slides.text: 'You are a word problem solver! Every time something is shared, used up, or given away in real life, you can write a subtraction equation.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child listen to a word problem, identify it as subtraction, solve using objects, and write the corresponding equation?

parent_notes: Word problems are where mathematics meets real life, and they are often the most challenging type of math for children because they require reading comprehension, operation identification, and computation all at once. The Montessori approach — acting it out with objects — removes the abstraction barrier. Always start with scenarios from the child's own life: their toys, their snacks, their friends. When the child creates their own word problem, they demonstrate deep understanding. Watch for the child who can solve with objects but struggles to write the equation — this is normal and the connection will strengthen with practice.

title: The Five Senses — Sense of Hearing
description: An in-depth exploration of the sense of hearing. The child learns about how ears work, conducts a sound walk, and classifies sounds by type and volume.
instructions:
1. 'Yesterday we explored sight. Today: HEARING! Your ears are incredible instruments.'
2. Show a simple diagram of the outer ear. 'Sound travels through the air as invisible waves. Your ear catches them!'
3. Experiment 1: Cup hands behind ears. 'Does everything sound louder? Your cupped hands catch more sound waves!'
4. Experiment 2: Sound walk — go outside or around the house for 3 minutes. List every sound heard.
5. Classify sounds: natural vs. human-made, loud vs. soft.
6. Record findings in the science journal with a two-column chart.

slides.heading: The Five Senses
slides.subheading: Our Amazing Ears — Sense of Hearing

slides.setup_instructions: Print or draw a simple ear diagram. Prepare a clipboard for the sound walk.

slides.text: 'Sound is invisible! It travels through the air as waves. Your ear catches those waves and sends messages to your brain.'
'Cup your hands behind your ears like this. Does everything sound louder? Your hands are catching more sound waves!'
'Now let's go on a SOUND WALK. For 3 minutes, be perfectly quiet and listen. Write down every single sound you hear.'
'Let's look at your list. Can we sort these sounds? Natural sounds like birds... and human-made sounds like cars.'

slides.prompt: In your science journal, make a two-column chart: Natural Sounds and Human-Made Sounds. Sort your sound walk list. Draw a picture of your favorite sound.

slides.text: 'You heard so many sounds! Your ears are always working, even when you are asleep. Hearing keeps us safe and connected to the world.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify at least 8 sounds during the sound walk and correctly classify them as natural or human-made?

parent_notes: The sound walk is one of the most powerful Montessori science activities because it requires silence — a skill your child has been developing since their first days of Montessori work. In silence, children notice sounds they normally filter out: the hum of the refrigerator, distant traffic, wind in trees, their own breathing. This heightened awareness is both scientific observation and mindfulness practice. The classification activity (natural vs. human-made) introduces a key scientific skill: sorting data into categories. If your child is interested, extend by discussing animal hearing: 'Dogs can hear sounds that are too high for our ears!'

title: Music Exploration — Making Sound Instruments
description: The child creates simple musical instruments from household materials and experiments with pitch, volume, and rhythm. This connects the hearing science theme with creative expression.
instructions:
1. 'We learned about hearing today. Now let's MAKE sounds with instruments we create ourselves!'
2. Present materials for 2-3 instruments:
   - Shaker: small container filled with rice or beans
   - Drum: overturned pot or box with a wooden spoon
   - Guitar: rubber bands stretched over an open box
3. Make each instrument together.
4. Experiment: 'How do you make it louder? Softer? Higher? Lower?'
5. Play a simple rhythm pattern. The child echoes it.
6. Free play: the child creates their own song or rhythm.
materials_needed: Open box and rubber bands (for guitar)

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all materials on a large work surface. Have examples of each instrument ready to show.

slides.text: 'Musicians make sounds with instruments. Today we are going to BUILD our own instruments and explore how sound works!'
'First, a shaker! Fill this container with rice. Close the lid tight. Shake it! Now try beans — does it sound different?'
'Next, a drum! Turn this pot upside down and tap with the spoon. Tap softly... now loudly! You control the volume.'
'Last, a stringed instrument. Stretch rubber bands over this box. Pluck them! A tight band makes a higher sound, a loose band makes a lower sound.'

slides.prompt: Play your instruments! Can you make a loud sound and a soft sound? A high sound and a low sound? Create a short song using all three instruments.

slides.text: 'You are a musician AND a scientist! You discovered that sound changes when you change how you play — louder, softer, higher, lower.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate volume control (loud/soft) and identify pitch differences (high/low) using their homemade instruments?

parent_notes: Making instruments from everyday objects is deeply Montessori — it shows the child that learning materials are everywhere, not just in purchased kits. The scientific concepts here are real: pitch is determined by the frequency of vibration (tight rubber bands vibrate faster = higher pitch), and volume is determined by the force applied. You do not need to explain this in technical terms, but the child's hands-on discovery lays the groundwork. Let the child experiment freely after the guided portion. Some children will spend a long time adjusting rubber band tension to get different notes. This curiosity-driven exploration is exactly what Montessori education cultivates.

title: Independent Work Cycle — Extended Period with Journal Reflection
description: The child completes an extended independent work period choosing four works, then writes a brief journal reflection about their experience. This prepares them for the longer work cycles of elementary.
instructions:
1. 'Today is an extended work period. You will choose FOUR works and take your time with each one.'
2. Set a gentle timer for 40 minutes.
3. The child works independently, choosing, completing, and returning works.
4. After the work period, provide a journal page: 'Draw or write about your favorite work today. What did you learn? What was easy? What was hard?'
5. The child completes the journal entry.
6. Share and discuss the journal entry together.
materials_needed: Journal or lined paper with drawing space

slides.setup_instructions: Refresh the shelves if needed. Prepare a journal page with: My Favorite Work Today (drawing space) and What I Learned (lined space).

slides.text: 'Today is a big work day! You will choose FOUR works — one more than usual. This is like what older students do in elementary school.'
'Take your time. There is no rush. Focus on each work completely before moving to the next.'
'When the timer chimes, finish your current work and put it away. Then it is time for your journal reflection.'

slides.prompt: Complete four works independently. Then draw and write about your favorite work in your journal: What was it? What did you learn? What was easy or hard?

slides.text: 'You worked independently for a long time today! Your journal entry shows your thinking. This is what real learners do — work, reflect, and grow.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sustain independent work for 40 minutes across four works and produce a meaningful journal reflection?

parent_notes: This extended work period prepares your child for elementary, where work cycles typically last 2-3 hours. The journal reflection is a powerful addition — it develops metacognition (thinking about thinking) and writing skills simultaneously. Do not worry about the quality of the journal entry at first. Some children will draw detailed pictures with one sentence; others will write several sentences with a quick sketch. Both are valid expressions of reflection. Over time, these journal entries become a beautiful record of your child's growth and interests. Save them — they are precious documentation of your child's Montessori journey.

title: Reading Comprehension — Retelling with Sequence
description: The child reads a short story and retells it in sequence using the words first, then, next, and finally. This develops narrative comprehension and oral language skills essential for writing.
instructions:
1. Present sequence words on cards: FIRST, THEN, NEXT, FINALLY.
2. 'When we retell a story, we use these words to keep events in order.'
3. Read a short story together (or the child reads independently).
4. 'Now retell the story using these words. FIRST, what happened?'
5. Guide the child through the retelling, placing each sequence card as they talk.
6. The child writes or draws 4 panels showing the story sequence.
7. Read the retelling aloud.
materials_needed: Short story at child's reading level
Sequence word cards (First, Then, Next, Finally)

slides.setup_instructions: Print sequence word cards large enough to place on the table. Prepare a paper folded or divided into 4 boxes.

slides.text: 'Today we will retell a story in ORDER. These words help us: FIRST, THEN, NEXT, FINALLY.' Show each card.
'Read this story carefully. When you finish, you will tell it back to me using our sequence words.'
'FIRST, what happened at the beginning? Place the FIRST card and tell me.' Continue with THEN, NEXT, FINALLY.

slides.prompt: Draw the four parts of the story in order on your story strip. Write a sentence under each picture using: First..., Then..., Next..., Finally...

slides.text: 'You retold the whole story in order! These sequence words help organize your thoughts — you can use them when you write your own stories too.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell a story in correct sequence using at least 3 of the 4 sequence words?

parent_notes: Retelling in sequence is a critical comprehension skill and a direct precursor to writing. When children learn to organize events using transition words, they are building the narrative structure they need for their own compositions. The four-panel format provides visual scaffolding — each box represents one part of the story. If your child can retell orally but struggles to write, let them draw first and add words after. The sequence words (first, then, next, finally) will become part of their writing vocabulary. You can practice this at any time: 'Tell me about your day using first, then, next, finally.'

title: Subtraction — Fact Families
description: The child discovers that addition and subtraction are related by exploring fact families. Using concrete materials, they see that 3 + 5 = 8, 5 + 3 = 8, 8 - 3 = 5, and 8 - 5 = 3 are all part of the same number family.
instructions:
1. Present 8 counters. Separate them into groups of 3 and 5.
2. '3 and 5 make 8. Write it: 3 + 5 = 8.'
3. 'Turn it around: 5 and 3 also make 8. Write: 5 + 3 = 8.'
4. 'Now start with 8 and take away 3. What is left? 5! Write: 8 - 3 = 5.'
5. 'Start with 8 and take away 5. What is left? 3! Write: 8 - 5 = 3.'
6. 'These four equations are a FACT FAMILY — they all use the same three numbers!'
7. The child creates 2-3 more fact families with different numbers.

slides.setup_instructions: Place counters on the mat. Have paper ready for writing equations.

slides.text: 'Did you know that addition and subtraction are related — like a family? Let me show you!' Place 8 counters on the mat.
Separate into 3 and 5. '3 plus 5 equals 8. And 5 plus 3 equals 8. Two addition facts!'
'Now watch: 8 minus 3 equals 5. And 8 minus 5 equals 3. Two subtraction facts! All four use the numbers 3, 5, and 8.'
'This is called a FACT FAMILY. If you know one fact, you can figure out the other three!'

slides.prompt: Create fact families for: 4, 6, and 10. Then 2, 7, and 9. Write all four equations for each family. Use counters to check.

slides.text: 'Fact families show that addition and subtraction are connected! When you know 6 + 4 = 10, you automatically know 10 - 4 = 6.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child generate all four equations in a fact family given three related numbers?

parent_notes: Fact families are one of the most important concepts in early mathematics because they reveal the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction. When a child truly understands this, they effectively halve the number of facts they need to memorize — knowing 3 + 5 = 8 gives them three more facts for free. The concrete materials make this relationship visible: the same 8 counters can be grouped as 3 and 5 or regrouped as 5 and 3, and taking away either group always leaves the other. This is NOT just a worksheet exercise — the hands-on discovery with objects builds genuine understanding that paper-only practice cannot achieve.

title: Community Helpers — The Scientist in the Field
description: Exploring how scientists work in the field — biologists in nature, geologists studying rocks, marine biologists in the ocean — and conducting a mini field study.
instructions:
1. 'All week we have been doing science experiments. Did you know that some people do science as their JOB? They are called scientists!'
2. Discuss different types of scientists: biologists study living things, astronomers study stars, marine biologists study the ocean.
3. 'What did scientists use to discover everything in your science books? Their senses! And also special tools.'
4. Present scientist tools: magnifying glass, ruler, scale, thermometer.
5. The child draws a picture of themselves as a scientist with their tools.
6. 'What would YOU like to study as a scientist?'
materials_needed: Pictures of different types of scientists
Scientist tools: magnifying glass, ruler, simple scale, thermometer
Lab coat or white shirt (optional, for dramatic play)

slides.heading: Community Helpers
slides.subheading: Community Helpers — The Scientist in the Field

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures of different scientists at work. Arrange tools on a tray.

slides.text: 'This week you have been a scientist! You observed, experimented, and recorded your findings. Some people do this every day as their job.'
'There are many kinds of scientists: biologists study plants and animals, chemists study substances, astronomers study space.'
'Scientists use tools to help their senses: a magnifying glass helps them SEE small things, a thermometer helps them FEEL temperature as a number.'

slides.prompt: Draw yourself as a scientist! What are you studying? What tools are you using? Write a sentence: 'I am a ___ scientist. I study ___.'

slides.text: 'You already think like a scientist — you observe, ask questions, and try experiments. The world needs curious people like you!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 2 types of scientists and describe what scientists do (observe, experiment, discover)?

parent_notes: Connecting the week's science work to real careers gives purpose and context to the child's learning. In Montessori education, community helpers are not just about jobs — they are about how individuals contribute to the greater good. Scientists improve medicine, protect the environment, and expand human knowledge. When the child draws themselves as a scientist, they are building identity: 'I can be a scientist.' This is especially important for children from underrepresented groups in STEM. Avoid gendered stereotypes — show diverse scientists. If your child is passionate about a particular area of science, research that type of scientist together.

title: Read-Aloud: All the Water in the World by George Ella Lyon
description: Reading 'All the Water in the World' by George Ella Lyon, a lyrical nonfiction picture book tracing the water cycle from rain to rivers to oceans and back again.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Where does water come from? Where does it go?'
2. Read aloud — the text is poetic and rhythmic, like water itself.
3. Follow the water cycle: rain, puddles, streams, rivers, ocean, evaporation, clouds, rain again.
4. Discuss: 'The same water has been here since dinosaurs! How is that possible?'
5. Talk about taking care of water: 'Why is it important?'
6. Connect to your own observations of rain, puddles, and streams.
materials_needed: All the Water in the World by George Ella Lyon
Optional: a glass of water to observe

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: All the Water in the World by George Ella Lyon

items: All the Water in the World book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. A glass of water makes a wonderful prop.

slides.text: Cover: 'This book is about all the water in the world. Where do you think water comes from?'
Read with flowing rhythm — the text moves like water. Katherine Tillotson's illustrations are luminous.
Discuss: 'Where does rain go? How does it get back up to the clouds? Is the water in your glass really, really old?'

slides.prompt: Draw the water cycle: rain falling, going into a puddle, flowing to a river, reaching the ocean, evaporating up to clouds, and raining again!

slides.text: 'All the water in the world goes round and round. The water you drink today might have been a dinosaur's puddle!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least three steps of the water cycle?

parent_notes: This poetic nonfiction book makes the water cycle accessible and magical for young children. It connects to Montessori's science curriculum and the child's natural curiosity about weather and nature. The conservation message is gentle but important. Consider doing a water cycle observation — leave a bowl of water in the sun and watch evaporation happen.
